Critic's Picks | Visual arts

Elizabeth Kramer, ekramer@courier-journal.com 7:52 p.m. EDT October 31, 2014

“Patience” created in 1996 by Richard Meitner using blown and enameled borosilicate glass is part of the Adele and Leonard Leight Collection and on exhibit at Local Speed. (Photo: Provided)

CONNECT 1 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE




A NEW LEIGHT ON GLASS

Louisvillians Leonard and Adele Leight — who have built an impressive collection of contemporary glass art and ceramics that dates to the 1920s — recently let New Orleans-based artists Stephen Paul Day and Sibylle Peretti curate an exhibit from the collection for the Speed Art Museum's Local Speed. Those works and ones by Day and Peretti are part of the exhibit called "Remix." Peretti sculpts glass to create often haunting human figures. Collections with her work include New Orleans Museum of Art, Pittsburgh's Carnegie Museum of Art and 21c Museum Hotel. Day works in glass and many other media to create project-based installations that are like imaginary worlds. Information: (502) 634-2700; changingspeed.org.

WHEN: Friday through Feb. 21. Opening reception with live music, cash bar, 5 to 10 p.m., Friday.

WHERE: Local Speed, 822 E. Market St.

COST: Free admission




“Top of the Morning” by Kathleen Lolley is one of many works in a show at WHY Louisville on Market Street. (Photo: Provided)


SURREAL AND FOLK

Artist Kathleen Lolley's charming yet haunting characters rooted in between the natural and spiritual worlds have drawn a lot of attention to her work — resulting in her illustration on the cover My Morning Jacket's 2002 album "Z" and mentions in ELLE and Domino magazines. A new exhibit of her work called "Blossom and Decay" consists of drawings, watercolor studies and shadow boxes and maintains her style that combines the surreal with folk qualities. Lolley credits family stories, folk tales and finding a discarded poster during her childhood with work by 15th century Dutch painter Hieronymus Bosch. Information: (502) 290-7778; www.whylouisville.com, kathleenlolley.com.

WHEN: Friday through Dec. 4

WHERE: WHY Louisville, 806 E. Market St.

COST: Free admission
